flow.context: Kat Goodhand is Retreatia's Business Development Executive and a Realtor in Steamboat Springs, CO. She's the front door for new property owners — Retreatia's growth pages literally say 'Reach out to Kat.' Prior role: Residence Manager and Owner Liaison at One Steamboat Place / Timbers Resorts (luxury), so she deeply understands high-end property standards and owner expectations. Retreatia manages roughly 240 units (77% condos), runs on TrackHS, and publicly promises 'a team of inspectors separate from cleaning after every guest' — that inspection promise is central to what Kat sells owners during onboarding. They're actively hiring a Housekeeping Supervisor and Owner Liaison right now, signaling scaling strain on QA. No direct shared connections with Sam, but Sam skied Jackson Hole last month — Steamboat is a peer ski market and the closest natural bridge.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Kat — I was up skiing Jackson Hole last month and got talking with a couple vacation rental managers about how they handle turnovers during peak season. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Casual, warm. Sound like someone who lives in her world — ski markets, PM operations. Don't rush the last line. Let 'have you heard my name tossed around' land.

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Rare but great. Shut up and let her talk. Whatever she says, bridge into her inspection workflow or how she pitches owners.

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — TRANSITION
heard_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call —
heard_no.note: Smile through this line. Self-deprecating then straight into pain. No awkward pause between this and the pain trigger.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow, maybe late morning?
bad_timing.note: Pick a specific day and time. Give her something to react to, not an open-ended 'when works for you.'

callback_set.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
callback_set.say: Perfect — I'll ring you then. Appreciate it, Kat.
callback_set.note: Write down the exact time immediately. Call back precisely when you said. This is a promise.

whos_this.label: GUARDED — PERMISSION ASK
whos_this.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, full transparency. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I called you specifically, and if it's not relevant you can totally hang up on me?
whos_this.note: Own it immediately. Honesty disarms. Don't sound apologetic — sound confident and direct.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION DENIED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally on me. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: Stay relaxed. You're splitting to learn the real reason. Frame it as doing HER a favor — nobody else will bother her.

rejection_try_referral.label: REJECTED — TRY REFERRAL
rejection_try_referral.say: Totally fair. Real quick — is there someone on the ops side at Retreatia who owns the turnover inspection workflow? I just don't want to keep bugging the wrong person.
rejection_try_referral.note: Kat is BD, not ops — but she knows the org chart cold. The GM is Viktorija Hristovska. If Kat gives a name, see if it matches. Don't name-drop unless she's struggling.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So I was talking to a BD lead at another ski market PM company — similar setup to you guys, about 250 units, mostly condos. She told me the toughest part of her job wasn't getting new owners to sign — it was keeping them past year one. Because every time the inspection team missed something — a gouge in the hardwood, a stained comforter, something small — and the owner heard about it from a guest review instead of from her team, it chipped away at the whole 'we inspect after every guest' promise she'd made during onboarding. She was spending half her time on owner saves instead of closing new doors.
pain_trigger.note: This pain is tailored to Kat's BD role — owner trust, not ops efficiency. Retreatia literally markets 'inspection after every guest' and Kat sells that promise to new owners. PAUSE after this. Let her react. Do not fill the silence.

branches.label: 'That's not really my area' / 'I'm on the BD side'
'We already have a solid process for that'

warm_response.label: THEY'RE WARM — STOP PITCHING
warm_response.say: Yeah — so I'm curious, when you're pitching a new owner on Retreatia, how do you talk about the inspection piece? Like is that something owners ask about upfront, or does it come up more after they've signed and something goes wrong?
warm_response.note: She's warm. Switch to questions IMMEDIATELY. This question is specific to her BD role — gets her talking about how inspections affect her pipeline. Listen and take notes.

branches.label: It's a selling point / owners ask about it
Comes up when something goes wrong

not_my_department.label: NOT MY AREA — PIVOT TO REFERRAL
not_my_department.say: Totally makes sense — you're focused on bringing owners in the door, not running the QA floor. Who on your team actually owns the inspection workflow? I know you guys have that whole separate inspection team — is there a head of ops or someone running that?
not_my_department.note: Kat works across ops, housekeeping, maintenance daily. The GM is Viktorija Hristovska. The housekeeping supervisor role is open. Let Kat tell you who's who — don't name-drop first.

branches.label: Gives a name (likely Viktorija or housekeeping lead)
Says try the general line / not sure
Actually, tell me more — this could help my pitch

discovery_owner_pitch.label: DISCOVERY — INSPECTION AS SELLING POINT
discovery_owner_pitch.say: That's interesting — so it's part of the pitch. When you tell an owner 'we inspect after every guest,' what does that actually look like on the ground? Like are your inspectors taking photos, filling out checklists, or is it more of a visual walkthrough?
discovery_owner_pitch.note: You're learning their actual inspection process through the lens of what Kat promises owners. Whatever she describes, listen for gaps — manual review, inconsistency across inspectors, photo volume nobody reviews.

branches.label: Not totally sure of the details

discovery_pain_stories.label: DISCOVERY — PAIN STORIES
discovery_pain_stories.say: Ugh, that's brutal. What kind of stuff typically slips through? Is it more cosmetic damage that builds up quietly, or the big stuff — a broken TV, a missing item — that causes the real fires?
discovery_pain_stories.note: She's venting about real problems. Let her go. Every story is ammunition for the solution pitch and the meeting. Take detailed notes.

discovery_photo_process.label: DISCOVERY — PHOTO PROCESS
discovery_photo_process.say: Got it — so photos are already part of the workflow. Roughly how many per turnover? And who's actually reviewing them — is it the same inspector, a manager, or does someone else go through them after?
discovery_photo_process.note: THE money question. If photos exist but nobody reviews them systematically, that's exactly where RapidEye sits. Retreatia uses TrackHS — photos may be going into Track and sitting there unreviewed.

branches.label: Describes review process or mentions volume challenge
Honestly not sure who reviews them

discovery_checklist_process.label: DISCOVERY — CHECKLIST PROCESS
discovery_checklist_process.say: Makes sense. Are they doing photos alongside the checklist, or is it purely visual — inspector walks through, checks the boxes, moves on?
discovery_checklist_process.note: Even if checklist-only today, RapidEye works with any photo step. Find out if photos exist anywhere in the flow — cleaners, inspectors, anyone.

branches.label: Photos are part of it too

discovery_not_sure.label: DISCOVERY — KAT DOESN'T KNOW DETAILS
discovery_not_sure.say: No worries — that's the ops team's world. Here's why I called you though: what you're selling owners on — that inspection promise — is exactly the thing we make bulletproof. Would it make sense for me to talk to whoever runs that side, and then loop you in so you can see how it strengthens your owner pitch?
discovery_not_sure.note: She may not know the inspection details, but she cares deeply about making her owner pitch airtight. Position this as helping HER close more owners, then get the referral.

branches.label: Yeah, let me connect you with someone
Tell me a bit more first

discovery_deeper.label: DISCOVERY — DIG DEEPER
discovery_deeper.say: And with 240-plus units — mostly condos, right? — how are you guys handling the volume during peak season? Like ski season right now, you're probably turning multiple units a day. Does the inspection quality hold up when volume spikes?
discovery_deeper.note: Use the research: 77% condos, ~240 units, actively hiring housekeeping supervisor. Peak ski season is NOW. This question should hit a nerve about consistency at scale.

branches.label: Acknowledges quality drops at peak / it's a challenge
We handle it fine / we're staffing up

hiring_angle.label: HIRING — SCALING PAIN
hiring_angle.say: Yeah I actually noticed you guys are hiring a housekeeping supervisor right now — which makes total sense at your scale. That's actually what caught my eye about Retreatia. The companies growing the fastest are usually the ones where inspection consistency starts to slip because the people doing it are also juggling ten other things.
hiring_angle.note: Shows homework. Ties their active hiring (housekeeping supervisor + owner liaison postings) directly to the pain RapidEye solves. Don't be creepy about it — mention it matter-of-factly.

solution_bridge.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
solution_bridge.say: So what we built — RapidEye plugs into your existing workflow. Your team's already taking photos during turnovers. We analyze them automatically — catches damage, missing items, staging issues, things that changed since last time. Since you guys are on Track, it sits right inside the tools your team already uses. No new process, no extra steps.
solution_bridge.note: One breath. Mention Track specifically — they use TrackHS. Don't oversell or list features. Immediately transition to the CTA.

cta_meeting.label: ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to seeing what that looks like? Not right now while I'm cold calling you — maybe 15 minutes later this week where I can show you what other ski market PMs are doing with their turnover photos?
cta_meeting.note: Low friction. 'Not right now' removes pressure. 'What other ski market PMs are doing' makes it a learning opportunity, not a sales pitch. Shut up after asking.

branches.label: I'm not the right person for this
We don't have budget right now
We already have something for that

book_meeting.label: BOOK IT NOW
book_meeting.say: Awesome — I've got Thursday pulled up. How's the afternoon look, say 2 o'clock your time?
book_meeting.note: Pick a specific day and time. Don't ask 'when works for you' — give her something to react to. Adjust if needed but stay in control of the calendar.

branches.label: Let me check and get back to you

pin_down_meeting.label: PIN IT DOWN
pin_down_meeting.say: Totally — tell you what, I'll shoot you an invite for Thursday at 2 and if that doesn't work just propose a new time right from the invite. That way it doesn't get lost. Best email — is it g-kat at retreatia dot com?
pin_down_meeting.note: Don't let it float to 'I'll get back to you' — that dies. Send the invite while on the phone. The likely email pattern is g-kat@retreatia.com — say it naturally to confirm.

meeting_booked.label: MEETING CONFIRMED
meeting_booked.say: Perfect — you'll see that invite from me in the next few minutes. Really appreciate you taking my cold call, Kat. Talk soon.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. Meeting is booked. Send the calendar invite within 60 seconds of hanging up. Keep it warm and short. Do not add anything else.

objection_no_budget.label: NO BUDGET — AGREE FIRST
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it — nowadays it's harder to keep a tool than to buy something new. Especially heading into the back half of ski season when every dollar's accounted for.
objection_no_budget.note: Agree genuinely. Reference seasonal budget pressure — ski season spending is real. Then split the objection.

split_budget.label: SPLIT THE BUDGET OBJECTION
split_budget.say: Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that budget this year is completely locked, or is it more that anything new has to go through a whole approval process?
split_budget.note: Two paths. 'Locked' = revisit later, sell the future look. 'Approval process' = there IS a path, you need to arm her with ammo for internal buy-in.

branches.label: Approval process / have to run it up

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE FUTURE LOOK
sell_test_drive.say: Makes total sense. You're probably not buying anything right now, and I respect that. But when budget does open up, the people who move fast are the ones who already know what's one, two, three on their list. Would you be open to just taking a look — not buying anything — so when the time comes, you've already seen it?
sell_test_drive.note: You're not selling the product. You're selling the meeting as a future planning move. Low commitment, high value framing.

sell_test_drive_approval.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE — APPROVAL PATH
sell_test_drive_approval.say: Totally — I figured. What if I did a quick 15-minute walkthrough with you, just so you have something concrete to show internally? Worst case it sits in your back pocket. Best case it makes the approval conversation a lot easier because the homework's already done.
sell_test_drive_approval.note: Position the meeting as making HER life easier when she pitches it up the chain. She's BD — she knows exactly how to sell things internally. Give her the material.

objection_have_process.label: ALREADY HAVE A PROCESS — AGREE
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with 240-plus units you'd have to have something solid in place. I'd be worried if you didn't.
objection_have_process.note: Agree warmly. Retreatia promises a separate inspection team — they clearly take this seriously. The question is whether it scales during peak volume. Then split.

split_process.label: SPLIT THE PROCESS OBJECTION
split_process.say: Just curious — is it that you're fully covered and everything's working great, or is it more that switching anything mid-ski-season would be a nightmare?
split_process.note: 'Working great' = hard to crack, try value offer. 'Switching is hard' = they know it's imperfect but timing is bad. That's your opening — RapidEye requires zero workflow change.

branches.label: Switching right now would be a pain

no_workflow_change.label: NO WORKFLOW CHANGE HOOK
no_workflow_change.say: Totally hear you — and that's actually the whole point. We don't replace anything. Your inspectors keep doing what they're doing, same photos, same process. We just analyze what they're already capturing. Nothing changes for your team — they wouldn't even know we're there.
no_workflow_change.note: This is the key differentiator for an objection about switching. RapidEye sits on TOP of their existing workflow. Emphasize zero disruption, then re-ask for the meeting.

objection_not_interested.label: NOT INTERESTED — AGREE
objection_not_interested.say: Totally fair — I should've assumed you'd be all set. Otherwise you probably would have reached out to us.
objection_not_interested.note: Disarm with agreement. Don't argue or get defensive. Then split to find the real reason.

split_interest.label: SPLIT THE INTEREST OBJECTION
split_interest.say: Just so I don't waste your time going forward — is it that turnover inspections aren't really a pain point for you guys, or is it more that you just hate cold calls? Honestly I get both.
split_interest.note: Humor helps. If not a pain point for HER, pivot to referral — she's BD, the ops team may care. If she hates cold calls, offer value in a different format.

branches.label: Not my area / not a pain point for me
I just hate cold calls / bad timing

value_offer.label: OFFER VALUE — MARKET INSIGHTS
value_offer.say: Totally fair. If nothing else — I work with PM companies across a bunch of ski markets, and I could share what the best operators are doing with their turnover QA at scale. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
value_offer.note: Last play before exit. You're offering pure value — no strings. 'Ski markets' is specific to her world. If this doesn't land, exit gracefully.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair — happy to do that. One quick question so I don't just send you a generic pitch deck: what would actually be useful to include? Like is it more about what other ski market PMs are doing, or more about how it'd fit with Track on the technical side?
send_email.note: Accept the email ask, then ask what matters to HER. This gives you intel AND extends the conversation. Mentioning Track shows you've done your homework.

email_confirmed.label: EMAIL CONFIRMED
email_confirmed.say: Done — I'll send that over today. And I'll throw a time suggestion in there for a quick call in case anything catches your eye. Best email — g-kat at retreatia dot com?
email_confirmed.note: Confirm the email address naturally using the likely pattern. Include a specific meeting time in the email. Follow up within 2 hours. Reference something specific from this conversation.

referral_get_details.label: GET REFERRAL DETAILS
referral_get_details.say: That'd be huge. Who would that be — is there a head of ops or someone running the inspection team directly?
referral_get_details.note: You're looking for Viktorija Hristovska (GM) or the housekeeping supervisor role. Let Kat volunteer the name naturally — don't name-drop unless she's stuck.

branches.label: Gives a title but not a name

referral_push_name.label: PUSH FOR THE NAME
referral_push_name.say: Got it — and if I can get a first name, I can put something tailored together so it actually lands instead of getting buried in the general inbox.
referral_push_name.note: Names make referrals real. Without a name, you're back to cold calling the main line.

branches.label: Can't give a name / try the main line

referral_confirm.label: CONFIRM REFERRAL — ASK TO USE HER NAME
referral_confirm.say: Perfect — and would it be cool if I mentioned you pointed me their way? That way it doesn't feel like a totally random cold call for them either.
referral_confirm.note: Using Kat's name when calling the ops person dramatically increases pickup and trust. Get explicit permission.

referral_thank.label: REFERRAL WRAP-UP
referral_thank.say: Really appreciate it, Kat. I'll reach out to them and keep it relevant. And hey — if you ever want to see how this could sharpen your owner pitch, I'm an open book. Thanks for your time.
referral_thank.note: Leave the door open with Kat. She's BD — even if she's not the buyer, she influences tool adoption because she sells the outcomes to owners. Send a brief thank-you email today.

referral_push_harder.label: PUSH HARDER FOR REFERRAL
referral_push_harder.say: Totally get it. Would you mind if I sent you a quick email you could just forward to whoever makes sense internally? That way it comes from you instead of some random cold outreach from me.
referral_push_harder.note: Forwardable email is low effort for Kat and high value for you. It gets you past the gatekeeper with an internal warm intro.

gatekeeper_initial.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper_initial.say: Hey — could you get me through to Kat? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_initial.note: First names only. Sound like you know her. Don't volunteer anything else. Pause and wait.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other vacation rental managers in the Steamboat area. Would you mind letting Kat know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Dose info slowly. 'A few other managers in the area' implies you're already in their world. Don't pitch. Don't explain RapidEye.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: We help a couple other property management companies in ski markets with their inspection workflows. I sent Kat a note — would you mind just giving her a heads up that Sam Parks called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Third attempt. If this doesn't work, take the voicemail gracefully. Don't burn the gatekeeper — you may need to call back.

gatekeeper_voicemail.label: GATEKEEPER — NOT AVAILABLE
gatekeeper_voicemail.say: No worries — when's usually the best time to catch Kat at her desk? And could I grab her direct line so I'm not tying up your front desk next time?
gatekeeper_voicemail.note: Get the callback window and direct number. Her phone likely ends in 0424 per research. If they give a number, compare. Write everything down.

branches.label: Gives a time or direct number

end_graceful.label: END GRACEFULLY
end_graceful.say: Totally understand. If anything ever comes up, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Kat.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. Stay warm and human. She may Google you after hanging up. Make sure your LinkedIn and RapidEye site are sharp.
